title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: 3D Printer Camp Group – Make One Now!
description: Do you want to build your own 3D Printer?

title: Introduction to Max/MSP/Jitter
description: Max/MSP/Jitter is a multimedia authoring environment that enables you to create programs for real-time manipulation of media (data, audio, video, 3d). It is used in performance and installations by artists, composers, and people just like you!
comment: Definately want to check this out.

title: Introduction to Max/MSP/Jitter
description: Max/MSP/Jitter is a multimedia authoring environment that enables you to create programs for real-time manipulation of media (data, audio, video, 3d). It is used in performance and installations by artists, composers, and people just like you!

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.
comment: Overlaps with the max/jitter class. Am in for the last hour.

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.
comment: By the way that was AWESOME!

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!
comment: Crud. Had rsvpd for this one specifically. Will teach me to point out the ambiguity….

title: Teaching Physical Computing
description: Do you teach physical computing?  Do you plan to teach it? Do you use it in your teaching?  Then this session is for you. There are plenty of people teaching using physical computing methods (electronics, microcontrollers, interaction design, fabrication) at many levels.  Let’s all get together and trade tips and tricks.

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…).

title: Product Design/DigiFab
description: We will be covering design tools (software and hardware) for digital fabrication.

title: ITP Mappathon: Content Making for Projection Mapping
description:
Step 1
 This week, we will learn how to make visual content using Modul8.
 We will use a png, a jpg and a movie files to make a moving image using Modul8. This method is a great tool to camp your idea.

title: Intro to Jitter & computer vision
description: Jitter is a video library for Max, by cycling 74. There’s a lot to explore in this toolset : real-time video manipulation, OpenGL, computer vision, physical modeling. So many things! You can find out about more about the package at the cycling74 website.

title: Acrylic Cutting and Bending
description: Learn a fast and easy way to prototype precision parts using the laser cutter.  And then literally take it in a new direction with the acrylic bender.  Quickly turn 2D parts into 3 dimensional objects.

title: Early version – From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Advanced, earlier date of my presentation on the 17th for those of you who wish to get ideas for your Camp projects a little sooner.

title: Dying Hungry: Learning to write from lede construction
description: “As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from uneasy dreams he found himself transformed in his bed into a monstrous vermin.”
comment:
1. How the hell did I miss this session?
 2. When/where are you going to do something similar….

title: Introduction to the Arduino Yún
description: So you want to network your microcontroller. These days, you’ve got a lot of options. Here’s the latest from Arduino, the Yún. This board has the heart of an Arduino Leonardo attached to a WiFi-equipped Linux processor.

title: Field trip to goveners island for the opening of Figment NYC 2013.
description: GIVEN THE RAIN I AM RESCHEDULING THIS TO SUNDAY….
comment:
Given the weather I want to reschedule this to Sunday
 http://www.wunderground.com/q/zmw:10001.4.99999

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description: So!  Sunday night, after you’ve hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it’s easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

title: Really Big Video Part 1
description: This session will introduce Big Building Mapping and Video Projection. I will begin by showing examples of site-specific and video mapping pieces and then we will map a real building using a spatial scan in Mad Mapper. For homework each camper will get a scan to work from and some tips on how to create giant projections. Part 2 of the session will allow campers to showcase their mapped work projected 3 stories tall on an actual building on broadway.

title: Film Cutting, Knot Tying, and The Ethics of Storytelling
description: In this participatory lecture, we will discuss the ethics behind story telling in interactive/immersive documentary, while cutting film and learning how to tie knots.

title: Prototype to Performance, Will it survive onstage??
description: So you just built this fancy “whatchamacallit” and it works perfectly on the bench, but what happens when you have to hand it off to someone else to be used in live performance, in the desert, on a mountain, in a forest or really anywhere else other than a nice neat controlled environment?  Build your device to be performance proof…

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.**
comment: If I can get up that early …

title: Intro to openFrameworks
description: This will be a quick intro into openFrameworks, aimed at people who never used it.

title: “Noticing” Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticing—seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises we’ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness. Participants will leave with their eyes wide open to the inspirations and complexity that surround us all and their minds full of techniques for learning more.

title: Introduction to Distributed Sensor Networks
description: Sensors are the future of distributed data. General-purpose computing is dissipating and becoming increasingly embedded into our lives. We will soon begin to move in a sea of data, our movements monitored and our environments measured and adjusted to our preferences, without need for direct intervention.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson – “the new literacies”
Dancing with the Arduino Due
description: Now that you’re a couple weeks into camp, you’ve probably bumped up against the glass ceiling of the hardware you’re using. Common issues expressed by campers in previous years have been “My death robot has no more memory for kill routines!”, or “I want to just plug a mouse into my Arduino  to control my hypnotronic LED array”

title: Faster Fashion – Rapid Prototyping and the Things We Wear
Creating a Killer Finish
description: We have two great tools in the shop for applying a fantastic finish to wooden and metal projects.

title: Beat Making for Babies
description: Beat Making for Babies is a fool proof introduction to making music with your computer. We’ll cover the basics of how to make simple beats using Midi, crafting beats from original & found sounds, and the seeds of combining our beats with emerging technologies.

title: Nudgeables Workshop
description: Sometimes we use secret codes to communicate with our friends, partners, or colleagues while in the company of a larger group of people: a nudge, a cough, a scratch of the nose; something that says “I’m thinking of you…”, “Save me from this conversation!”, or “Let’s get out of here!”.  What if our clothing could communicate these messages for us?

title: Midi, Sysex, and the Arduino. New tricks for an old dog.
description: unable to attend this day but would love to get notes on this afterwards if anyone can share
comment: I want to do a more generalized “make a midi device” workshop on the 16th and do this session on the following saturday. wIll this work for you?

title: End-of-Camp Shindig
description: Half show & tell, half party, the End of Camp Shindig is an opportunity to celebrate the month we’ve spent together and share what we’ve created.

title: Camp Fellows Lightening Talks!
description: Fellows will be giving 5 minute action packed talks on their work and time during ITP Camp!
